projects.name: Bike Finder
projects.description:
You will conceive and prototype an interface for finding and selecting a bicycle to purchase from on online store.

From one perspective, this is very straightforward: we've all used online stores to find and buy things. From another perspective, you'll discover a multitude of decisions you must make as a designer in order to accomplish the task. Among other things, you'll need to ask:

  • Who are my stakeholders?
  • What are they trying to accomplish?
  • What do they already know?
  • What do they need to know?
  • What do they care about?
  • What constitutes success?

This project is not about inventing something new, or making something beautiful. Rather, it is about recognizing and applying what's appropriate, and making something that works well for the people using it. The most successful solutions will likely be largely transparent to the user's conscious mind.

The final product of the project will be a clickable html prototype that allows you to demonstrate your solution. It will not include the check-out process, nor parts of the site un-related to the process of selecting a bicycle. It will not include any 'real' programming, or dynamic data. For instance, you should not attempt to make a 'search' feature actually search. It will include everything necessary to clearly convey how the interface will work. Therefore, a search button should take us to a view that looks like search results.

deliverables.name: Research: UI Conventions
deliverables.description: You probably have plenty of experience as an online shopper, and the user-interface conventions used by online stores probably feel very familiar to you. But have you ever taken the time to identify them? Let's do some shopping for various items, with an eye focused on UI. We'll make some observations and see what patterns emerge.
deliverables.instructions:
With a partner, buy four different item, each at a different online store. (Don't check out, just get as far as the 'Add to Cart' button.) Before you start, pre-select items that are specific, that have some options (size, color, horse-power, capacity, etc.), and that represent a variety of needs and price-points. (An example list: a dark grey cable-knit sweater, a riding lawn mower, a two-line high-performance kite, a mid-range gaming laptop.) Make sure at least two items come from 'niche' stores, not big-box retailers. For each store and item, document the following:

  • What UI elements did I see and/or interact with while finding, comparing, selecting, and configuring the specific product?
  • Have I seen this UI element before in other contexts?
  • Did I know what this element would do before I interacted with it? Why?
  • What general problem is this element designed to handle?
  • Why was it used in this context? Is it successful?

Discuss with your partner as you go. Perhaps take turns being shopper and observer. Together, see if you can put names to things: 'Query field. Checkbox. Drop-down selector. Results list.' Don't limit yourself to just clickable things, also note the contextual affordances that help you understand what's happening: titles, labels, icons, etc. Make particular note of any confusion/mistakes/wrong turns you make. What misdirected you?

When you are done, summarize your findings:

  • What elements or patterns seem universal?
  • Did I see anything that felt different or unusual?
  • What elements or patterns were specific to the store or product?
  • Were there any patterns or techniques that made one store stand out? Could the other stores have applied that technique successfully?
  • Finally, how did you feel when interacting with these sites? When were you happiest/most comfortable? When were you disrupted/confused/bothered?

Feel free to trade/combine observation notes with your partner, but write your own concluding summaries. Structure your observations, notes, and summaries as an HTML document, then upload via Github, at the path shown below.

deliverables.name: Product Knowledge
deliverables.description:
If we're going to sell bikes, we need to know about them and how people use them. So let's do some product and user research. Some things we might care about:

  • The physical product (materials, options, specifications)
  • Product variations (sizes, types and purposes, quality range, performance range, price range, brands)
  • Bike users (demographics, purpose, frequency of use, motivators)
  • The buying experience (Where bikes are sold, by whom, purchase considerations)

Sources for this information might include:

  • Your own experience/knowledge
  • Your friends/peers experience/knowledge
  • Online stores
  • Local bike shops
  • Online groups (clubs, forums, social media)
  • Other online buyer's guides

Finally, just like you did in your general UI research, 'buy' a bike at a few different online retailers. For now, focus on what YOU would want if you were actually buying a bike for yourself today. What would you use it for? What features do you care about? How will you know if it fits you? How will you select a brand and price point?
deliverables.instructions: Educate yourself about bikes and bike users, considering the factors and sources noted above. Challenge yourself to push past what you already know – find some suprises. Create an HTML document that lists the sources you used and briefly describes how you used them. Then summarize and analyze. What big questions will a buyer will be faced with? What priorities might they have? What did you run into that you didn't understand, and now you do?

deliverables.name: Personas
deliverables.description: Define and document a persona with your team.
deliverables.instructions: With your team, create a document describing your assigned persona. Be sure to include the elements of a persona as we defined them in class. Post the persona as an HTML document.

references.name: Personas - Why and How You Should Use Them
references.description: A reference providing some insight into what personas are, how to create and use them, and how they fit into the design thinking process.

deliverables.name: User Stories - Existing Site
deliverables.description: Embody the person your team created, and write user stories describing their experience on a real website.
deliverables.instructions: Select a real website for purchasing a bicycle, then 'be' the persona your team defined as you go through the purchasing process once again. Break the process down into a series of small, discrete objectives, following the User Story pattern: "As a < type of user >, I want < some goal > so that < some reason >." Write the these objectives down in an HTML document, provide context and style sufficient to let somebody else understand what you've documented, and post it.

references.name: What is a user story? Let me Google that for you!
references.description: I don't have a reference I consider definitive, so I leave it to you to interpret/assimilate what you find.

deliverables.name: User Stories - Aggregated
deliverables.description: Share your user stories with your peers.
deliverables.instructions:
Transcribe the user stories you wrote into the Google Sheet referenced below. Everybody else will do the same, and we'll end up with a combined set of stories we can all reference.

Once your user stories are transcribed, consider how you might want to organize this document further. But don't actually do it yet, at least to the master document!

references.name: Google Sheet: Bike Finder User Stories
references.description: This is the document where we'll collect all of our user stories.

deliverables.name: Feature Organization
deliverables.description: Create a document that organizes your high-level ideas about what solutions you propose to use, and how they'll fit together.
deliverables.instructions:
1. Read through the user-stories gathered in our previous deliverable. If you choose, make your own copy of that user-story sheet, and consolidate/organize further than we have in class.
  2. Identify possible UI solutions to address the stories. Not necessarily 1-for-1, just let the stories suggest ideas for components. A menu. A big photo. A search bar. An expanding drawer. Sometimes a single component such as a checkbox is enough. Sometimes you may end up with a set of components that work together, such as a search-field, search button, and results list. Keep an eye out for solutions that address more than one story/need, or that can be enhanced to address additional needs. For instance, a basic search bar might be enhanced with an 'auto-suggest' feature.
  3. Organize your solutions into pages, or views. What views need to exist? What responsibilities does each view have?
  4. Format your decisions in a document (or set of documents) that conveys as much as possible about your decisions, with as little effort as possible. The idea is to communicate a plan that's both easy to follow, and easy to change.

deliverables.name: Low-Fidelity Wireframes
deliverables.description: Create low-fidelity wireframes that visualize your proposed layout.
deliverables.instructions:
Create wireframes with whatever tool you choose, but stay low-fidelity. Don't waste time making it pretty: make it CLEAR. At the same time, do not over-simplify in terms of information. Provide enough information so we can understand what's happening. If a product in the list includes a title or a price, show those things.

Don't be satisfied with your first run at it... it's probably incomplete. Expect to iterate. Practice 'using' your wireframes with our personas. Can you complete the user-stories for each persona? Use deliverable.json to upload multiple versions as needed.

UPDATED REQUIREMENT (2018-02-05): Iterate and update per the in-class guidance.

references.name: Google Doc: Abe's Feedback on Revised Low-Fidelity Wireframes

deliverables.name: Visual Mockups
deliverables.description: Create mockups that present the final decisions you made in wireframing, along with base style choices that make it presentation friendly.
deliverables.instructions:
After you're certain your wireframes represent a complete set of functional decisions, it's time to create a high-fidelity visual mockup that is client-facing. Your aim is to present your UI solutions in a way that provides not only clear functional direction, but clear style direction. Don't worry about brand, or about any elements of the page not related to the bike finder. Better to leave those very loosely defined, with a clear distinction between what is and is not 'fully-realized.' Focus on hierarchy, legibility, and clarity. Aim for your UI elements to be the unobtrusive frame in which the content is displayed.

This mockup will become a clickable prototype in next steps, but for now, just make a series of pages that 'loop' when clicked: clicking anywhere on home takes me to list, anywhere on list takes me to detail, anywhere on detail takes me back to home.

deliverables.name: Clickable Prototypes
deliverables.description: Create presentation-ready prototypes with enough functionality to demonstrate a 'typical' path through the bike-finding process.
deliverables.instructions:
When your mockups are ready, add a layer of interactivity by positioning 'hotspots' that we can use to walk through them. Fundamentally you're delivering a series of rendered images, one-per-page, but by adding a hot-spot layer on top, we can simulate user actions leading to expected results, such as clicking a search bar and getting to the search results view, or clicking a thumbnail to get to a bike detail view.

You may also consider adding visual layers the user can show/hide with a click or over, such as a menu flyout, or expanded filter control. These could be smaller absolutely-positioned images which are simply set to display:none; until the user hovers a hot-spot.

Make sure your prototype is self-sufficient. In other words, make sure the rest of can click through your prototype successfully without your input or explanation.

Upload with enough time to spare that we don't run into awkward caching problems while trying to present to the class and our guest reviewers!

references.name: Hotspot demo source
references.description: Abe's down'n'dirty demo for creating 'invisible' hotspots.

projects.name: Free Apartment Promotion
projects.description:
Wish you had a posh pad this year, and didn't have to pay for it? Design a promotional sweepstakes in which one lucky winner gets free rent for a year!

A few things about the promotion you'll need to know:

  • Client: E.Z. Properties, Inc.
  • Promotion name: (To be determined by you)
  • Prize: Winner recieves a rental contract with E.Z. Properties, Inc., with one year already paid.
  • Eligibility: Open to Washington University students
  • Entry Limitations: One entry per person.
  • Starts: April 1, 2018
  • Ends: June 1, 2018
  • Prize drawing: June 7, 2018
  • Winner announced: June 15, 2018
  • Purpose: Gather contact info for use in email and social-media marketing of apartments to students.

What you ultimately deliver will be a prototype that is fully realized in HTML and CSS, but without any javascript or back-end programming to support it. We will design primarily for mobile-sized devices, but your prototype should have a reasonable strategy for responsive layout. Put another way, it should look its finest at mobile sizes, but should not break at any size.

Project Objectives:

  • Recognize and balance competing stakeholder interests.
  • Design an experience, not just a layout.
  • Design for edge-cases, branching flows, conditional situtations.
  • Design feedback mechanisms such as form validation and error pages.
  • Practice HTML/CSS and responsive layout skills.

deliverables.name: Flow Chart
deliverables.description: Create a process diagram (aka "Flowchart") to illustrate all possible user experiences within this simple promotional microsite.
deliverables.instructions: Use whatever tools you like, but post the final product either as an image on an HTML page, or as a link pointing to a web-viewable document. Arrange things so that they are legible and clearly organized.

references.name: Flow Chart
references.description: This is what I mean by a flow chart.

references.description: The steps we expect/hope a person takes to complete the experience.

deliverables.name: Content Document
deliverables.description: Write the copy that a visitor will see as they experience your site. Consider what the site hopes to accomplish, as well as what the user needs in order to accomplish it. Write the actual words that will appear on the page. Be detailed and structured. Consider titles and headlines, body copy, labels, captions, error messages, button and menu names, etc., and make sure the document you create clearly delineates those things. Think of this as a reference document that another designer would use to build out the content this site.
deliverables.instructions: Create this document in HTML. Use h1-h6 tags, p tags, ol, ul, li tags as semantically appropriate to create clear hierarchy. Don't worry about style, the style that your browser applies to these elements by default is fine.

deliverables.name: Style Reference
deliverables.description: Explore visual style options for the apartment promotion, and create a reference document that sets a clear visual direction. As with the content document, think of this as a document some other designer could use as a reference for your intentions. Build the reference you would want to receive.
deliverables.instructions: The exact form of the reference is up to you (mood board, style tile, sample page, etc.), but post it as an image embedded on an HTML page. Better yet, post multiple iterations/versions using deliverable.json.

deliverables.name: Page Mockups
deliverables.description:
Design a complete set of pages for your site. A few things to consider:

  • Global elements. What carries over from page to page, what doesn't?
  • Content. How effectively are you explaining what you want the user to do? How are you engaging them?
  • Forms. Take the time to find examples of web forms that are well designed, and evaluate what makes them work. How can you arrange a form that is both functional and painless for the user? What instructions or other context must you provide? Also, what happens visually when the form must display a validation message?
  • Completeness. Do your pages address all the scenarios modeled in your flowchart?
deliverables.instructions:
Post the pages as images embedded on HTML pages. Link the pages together in sequence.

Alternatively, 'design in the browser' using HTML/CSS. For those more comfortable with these tools, this may well be a simpler and more efficient approach.

Remember that the site must work at any size, but the mobile experience is our optimal target.

deliverables.name: HTML Prototype
deliverables.description: Based on your mockup, build the site with HTML, CSS, and Javascript as needed.
deliverables.instructions:
Make every link/button work in a way that allows us to experience the site completely. You don't need to do anything to actually save the data submitted on forms, but find a way to simulate the form submit experience, including the display of validation messages (e.g. 'Sorry, please enter a wustl email address.'). Also, find a way to simulate the experience in all three phases: before the promotion is open, while it's open, and after it's over.

Remember that the site must work at any size, but the mobile experience is our optimal target.

projects.name: Configurator
projects.description:
If you've ordered Pizza online, you know what a 'configurator' is — the interface by which you step through the various choices/options available to 'customize' something you want to describe. Thin-crust or deep dish, light cheese or heavy, Which meats? Which veggies?

In this project, you will design a configurator interface — but the object being configured is up to you. Could be pizza if you like, but could also be something like an airline ticket. The choice is yours... within some parameters:

  • The item being configured must have a finite set of pre-defined options that can be clearly articulated and easily understood.
  • Completion should be possible in no more than 3–5 steps.
  • The item must be commonly understood, requiring only a minimum of 'education' in order to configure.
  • Abe must approve it. :)

This project does not have a defined deliverable, other than to say the finished product of your work should easily allow anybody to simulate the configuration process. You may choose to actually build and program the configurator in html/css/js, you may choose to build a clickable prototype, you may choose to only provide a series of mockups. You should, however, play to your strengths. Decide on a topic and a final deliverable that showcases your abilities, and maximizes the value of the time you spend.

What will I be looking for? Clarity of purpose. Ease of use. Evidence of a strong work ethic. A self-sufficient end-product. Reasoned UX choices. Transparently usable and accessible UI. Ultimately, that it shows well!

deliverables.name: Proposal
deliverables.description: Write a proposal articulating the object you intend to configure, the final deliverable you expect to create, how that deliverable plays to your strengths, and what you expect to be able to show as progress in each class session between today and the final day of class.
deliverables.instructions: Create and upload your proposal as HTML. We will refer to it as we check progress through this project. I don't expect you to meet every goal you set perfectly, but I will expect you to meet me each week with either a met objective, or a revised plan. Use deliverable.json for plan revisions.

deliverables.name: Flow Chart and/or Options Lists
deliverables.description: Create a reference document that walks us through the specific configuration options of your object 'on paper'.
deliverables.instructions: The document may be visual or textual, but should clearly communicate what the configuration steps are, and what options are available at each step. Be specific. It is not sufficient to use placeholder values. Upload the document as HTML. If you build a visual flowchart, embed it as an image.
